Award.AwardTitle: Charting the Structure of the Milky Way Stellar Halo and Disk
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator seeks to understand our Milky Way galaxy. The Milky Way has dozens of smaller dwarf galaxies in orbit around it. These dwarf galaxies are being ripped apart by our galaxy's gravity into long streams of stars. Some of these streams encircle the entire galaxy. The investigator recently discovered that the disk of the Milky Way, which includes the spiral structure, has previously unknown 'ripples'. These ripples are believed to form when smaller dwarf galaxies fall into the Milky Way, just as a pebble dropped into a pond produces ripples on the surface of the water. By mapping the density of stars throughout the Milky Way, this project model of the interaction between the Milky Way galaxy and the dwarf galaxies orbiting it. These models will help us understand where dark matter is located. The models also teach us how the spiral arms of galaxies are made and sustained.

This project will train undergraduate students in science and computing. The investigator will engage the public in the scientific process through sustained public outreach initiatives. Public outreach will include science web pages, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube videos, Reddit Ask Me Anything (AMA) sessions, opportunities to observe the sky through small telescopes, and hands-on outreach activities that will reach thousands of children, teens, adults, and seniors. A relationship will be maintained between the investigators and the ~20,000 people, at any given time, who volunteer their personal computers to create the MilkyWay@home supercomputer.

The investigator will map the three dimensional stellar density in the disk and halo of our galaxy, using Sloan Digital Sky Survey main sequence and turnoff stars in the galaxy's halo. The investigator will use the technique of statistical photometric parallax to make the density maps. This technique recovers the underlying density distribution without measuring the distance to each individual star, because only the intrinsic brightness distribution is required.

The outer disk and the stellar halo will be mapped with turnoff stars. Main sequence stars, which are intrinsically dimmer, will be used to trace the density of closer stars in the Milky Way disk. The investigator will map the dominant substructures, including the vertical oscillations of the stellar mid-plane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported a project to understand why galaxies like ours look the way they do. We did this by mapping the density of stars in the Milky Way galaxy. There are two major parts to the distribution of stars in our galaxy: the disk stars and the halo stars. Disk stars like the Sun are mostly on circular orbits around the Galactic center. They are located close to a flat plane called the Galactic plane. The halo stars are a mostly spherical distribution of stars that surround the disk. The halo contains "tidal streams" of stars that are formed when small galaxies fall into our galaxy and are ripped apart by the gravitational force of the Milky Way. A dwarf galaxy that fell into the Milky Way a billion years ago could become a tidal stream that we see today. The purpose of mapping the stellar density is to understand how the features we see in the halo and disk form and evolve.

We used stars from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey that were on the northern side of the Galactic plane. We mapped the spatial density of the stars in three large tidal streams in the halo. One of them, the Perpendicular Stream, was a new discovery. We also mapped the spatial density of a background of stars that were not in these streams. We counted how many stars are in each of these components of the stellar halo, and found the shape of each component. The density functions were fit using MilkyWay@home. MilkyWay@home uses contributed computer processors from tens of thousands of volunteers at any given time. We need a large number of processors because we fit complicated functions with twenty or more parameters to the data.

We showed that we could use information about the positions of stars in tidal streams to determine how much dark matter was in the original dwarf galaxy that fell into the Milky Way. Although no one has been successful in detecting dark matter directly, we think it exists because stars move as if pulled by the gravitational force of some unseen matter. By studying tidal streams of stars, we hope to better understand the dark matter in dwarf galaxies that fall into the Milky Way. We can also study the dark matter in our own galaxy. This work also used MilkyWay@home to run simulations of dwarf galaxies falling into our galaxy. Using these simulations, we could find the dwarf galaxy shape that makes a tidal stream that looks like the actual stream.

We looked at the velocities of disk stars that are close to the Sun. Although these stars are on mostly circular orbits around the Milky Way, there are small differences from the circular orbit. These differences vary from place to place in the disk. The velocity and density differences move like waves through the disk. It is believed that these waves are caused by dwarf galaxies falling into our galaxy. As a dwarf galaxy falls in, it makes waves in the disk star component and then it gets pulled apart by the Milky Way's gravity into tidal streams.

We also studied the Virgo Overdensity, which is a very large concentration of stars in the Milky Way halo. Previous authors have found many groups of stars in the Virgo Overdensity that are moving in the same direction. Many tidal streams have also been found in the Virgo Overdensity. We matched velocity data from the Gaia satellite with information from previous surveys to find the three-dimensional positions and velocities of stars. We then showed that all of the previously discovered moving groups and streams were actually stars from a single dwarf galaxy. This dwarf galaxy was pulled apart when it fell through the center of our galaxy. We called this event the Virgo Radial Merger (VRM). We believe that this merger event is the same one that made the Gaia sausage, which is a similar merger event that was found by other astronomers using stars near the Sun. However, we have suggested a much more recent merger for the VRM than was suggested for the Gaia sausage.

In doing this research, twenty-six undergraduate students were mentored in research projects. Many of these students have gone on to graduate school in physics or astronomy. Many other students used the computational and data mining skills obtained by these research internships to get jobs in finance, e-commerce, data mining, data analytics, aerospace, or defense.

The faculty and students that are supported by this grant participate in a wide variety of outreach activities. Activities include: mentoring high school research projects, running public observing programs, supporting a non-profit astronomy education organization, giving public lectures, and serving as panelists for public events. We involve the public in research through MilkyWay@home, its related website, and a variety of social media platforms.
